unnormalised: Hey guys, someone asked me about taking a personal loan for a cousin's wedding. Is it a good idea? Honestly, it's tricky. On one hand, you want to help family. On the other, personal loans come with interest rates that can be pretty steep, like 12% or even 15% p.a. These rates can climb even higher depending on your credit score. You gotta be super sure you can repay it on time, every month, or else your CIBIL score will take a beating.
normalised: Hey guys, someone asked me about taking a personal loan for a cousin's wedding. Is it a good idea? Honestly, it's tricky. On one hand, you want to help family. On the other, personal loans come with interest rates that can be pretty steep, like twelve percent or even fifteen percent per annum. These rates can climb even higher depending on your credit score. You gotta be super sure you can repay it on time, every month, or else your C-I-B-I-L score will take a beating.

unnormalised: Think about the EMI, right? If you take a loan of, say, ₹2 lakhs for 3 years, the EMI could be around ₹6,500 - ₹7,000. Can you comfortably manage that every month? If you miss payments, the bank will slap on late payment fees, which can be another Rs. 500-750 per missed EMI. Before you know it, you're in a debt trap.
normalised: Think about the E-M-I, right? If you take a loan of, say, rupee two lakhs for three years, the E-M-I could be around rupee six thousand five hundred to rupee seven thousand. Can you comfortably manage that every month? If you miss payments, the bank will slap on late payment fees, which can be another rupees five hundred to seven hundred and fifty per missed E-M-I. Before you know it, you're in a debt trap.

unnormalised: Also, consider your cousin's actual needs. Is a lavish wedding really necessary? Maybe suggest alternatives like a simple ceremony and a smaller gathering. A smaller loan of say, ₹50,000 from friends and family may be better. See if other family members can chip in too! You could also look at options like borrowing against gold, but even that has its own risks.

unnormalised: If you still decide to go for the loan, shop around for the best rates. Check with different banks like HDFC Bank, ICICI Bank, and SBI. You can also compare rates online at sites like BankBazaar or PaisaBazaar. Don't just jump at the first offer. Look at processing fees, pre-payment charges, and all that jazz.

unnormalised: Ultimately, think long and hard about this. Lending money, even to family, can strain relationships. Make sure everyone's on the same page about the loan terms and repayment schedule. Consider a written agreement, you know, just to be safe. Nobody wants a fight over Rs. 100! Good luck!
